facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 194 and 195 of 1969 filed by special leave in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 194 and 195 of 1969. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment and order dated November 21, 1968 dismissing appeals

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1968 of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 211 and 232 of 1966 and Criminal E.C. No. 1643 of 1966.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate order dated 30 November 1965 acquitting respondents in one case

anchor.surface_text: against the order of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate dated 30 November, 1965 and the order of the Sessions Judge dated 16 November, 1965 acquitting the respondents.

facts.text: Sessions Judge order dated 16 November 1965 acquitting respondents in the other case

anchor.surface_text: Sessions Judge dated 16 November, 1965 acquitting the respondents. The question which falls for consideration in these appeals is the interpretation of section 40(2) of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1969, acts complained of occurred on 25 July 1964

anchor.surface_text: The acts complained of in Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1969 occurred on 25 July, 1964 and the complaint was filed on 18 May, 1965.

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1969, complaint filed on 18 May 1965

anchor.surface_text: complaint was filed on 18 May, 1965. In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969 the acts complained of occurred on 20 June, 1964 and the complaint was filed on 15 January, 1965.

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969, acts complained of occurred on 20 June 1964

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969 the acts complained of occurred on 20 June, 1964 and the complaint was filed on 15 January, 1965.

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969, complaint filed on 15 January 1965

anchor.surface_text: the complaint was filed on 15 January, 1965. The appellants contentions are three-fold.

facts.text: Respondents prosecuted for violation of rules 9, 53, 64, 67, 68, 70, 71, 66 and 226 of Central Excise Rules

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in both the appeals were prosecuted for violation of rules 9, 53, 64, 67, 68, 70, 71, 66 and 226 of the Central Excise Rules punishable under section 9(b) and (d) of the Act

facts.text: Accused No.1 in CA 194 was licensee of Paulraj Match Works, Nallichatram; Accused No.2 accountant

anchor.surface_text: The complaint was filed against accused No.1 who was the licensee of Paulraj Match Works, Nallichatram and accused No. 2 who was the accountant in the factory

facts.text: On 25 July 1964, accused in Paulraj Match Works affixed cut and torn banderols to matches to evade Rs. 577.42 excise duty

anchor.surface_text: on 25 July, 1964 the accused being proprietor and accountant respectively of Paulraj Match Works at Nallichatram were found to have affixed cut banderols and torn banderols to the matches

facts.text: RG1 register not written from 2 July 1964; RG3 not correctly maintained; shortage of 50 leaves of banderols

anchor.surface_text: The further details of the complaint were that the register R.G.1 was not written out from 2 July, 1964 and R.G. 3 register was not correctly maintained. There was also a shortage of 50 leaves of banderols in stock.

facts.text: Accused No.1 in CA 195 licensee of Meenachi Match Works; No.2 husband running factory and maintaining accounts

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969 the complaint was against accused No.1 the licensee of Meenachi Match Works and accused No. 2 husband of accused No 1 who was running the factory

facts.text: On 20 June 1964, Central Excise staff found Meenachi factory working at night with cut banderols pasted to evade duty

anchor.surface_text: on 20 June, 1964 the Central Excise staff visited the factory and found that the factory was working at night. On inspection it was found that cut banderols instead of full banderols had been pasted

facts.text: Excess matches cleared without entry or payment, depriving government of Rs. 2437.50 duty during 1963-64 and 1964-65 up to 20 June 1964

anchor.surface_text: it was found that during 1963-64 and 1964-65 upto 20 June, 1964 the licensee had actually cleared without entry in the official Central Excise Records and without payment of duty a quantity of matches

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate acquitted accused on 30 November 1965 in CA 194 holding prosecution barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1969 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on 30 November, 1965 acquitted the accused of the charges and held that the bar of limitation under the section applied

facts.text: Complaint received by SDM on 18 May 1965; inspection on 25 July 1964; limitation expired 25 January 1965

anchor.surface_text: The complaint was received in the Court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on 18 May, 1965. The inspection of factory by the Central Excise staff was on 25 July, 1964. The Sub-Divisional Magistrate therefore held that computing the period of six months from the date, the last date within which the complaint should have been laid would be 25 January, 1965.

facts.text: In CA 195, Sub-Divisional Magistrate found respondents guilty on 6 July 1965

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on 6 July, 1965 found the respondents guilty.

facts.text: Sessions Judge at Ramanathapuram acquitted respondents on 16 November 1965 holding prosecution barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge on 16 November, 1965 set aside the conviction and sentence and acquitted the respondents. The Sessions Judge held that the bar of limitation under the section operated against the State

facts.text: High Court dismissed State appeals maintaining acquittals on limitation grounds

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment dated 21 November, 1968 of the High Court at Madras dismissing the appeals filed by the appellant against the order of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate dated 30 November, 1965

facts.text: Appellant contends section 40(2) applies only to Government servants

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contentions are three-fold. First, the section applies only to Government servants.

facts.text: Respondents contend section 40(2) bars prosecution as instituted after six months

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contention on the other hand is that the section applies to prosecution of the respondents for violation of the provisions of the Rules and the Act.

facts.text: Prosecutions also under sections 420/511/109 IPC

anchor.surface_text: punishable under section 9(b) and (d) of the Act and also under section 420 read with section 511 of the Indian Penal Code and section 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court found prosecutions barred by section 40 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the prosecution in both the cases was barred by the rule of limitation in section 40 of the Act.

issues.text: The question which falls for consideration in these appeals is the interpretation of section 40(2) of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls for consideration in these appeals is the interpretation of section 40 2  of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 hereinafter referred to for brevity as the Section and the Act.

issues.text: whether the section applies only to Government servants

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contentions are three-fold. First, the section applies only to Government servants.

issues.text: whether the words 'anything done or ordered to be done under this Act' in the section mean any act in violation of the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Second, the words anything done or ordered to be done under this Act in the section do not mean any act in violation of the provisions of the Act.

issues.text: whether the protection given under the section is only for actions done inadvertently or mistakenly but not for acts done deliberately and maliciously

anchor.surface_text: Third, the protection given to Government servants under the section is for actions done inadvertently or mistakenly but not for acts done deliberately and maliciously.

issues.text: whether section 40(2) bars the prosecution instituted after six months for violation of the provisions of the Rules and the Act

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contention on the other hand is that the section applies to prosecution of the respondents for violation of the provisions of the Rules and the Act.

arguments.claim: The section applies only to Government servants

anchor.surface_text: First, the section applies only to Government servants.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of good faith in relation to act done. Good faith is one of the aspects in section 40 1 . The present appeals do number turn on sub-section  1  of sec

arguments.court_reasoning: Sub-section (2) lacks words restricting to government servants unlike sub-section (1); wide amplitude applies to any person; contrasted with other statutes that explicitly limit to govt/officers

arguments.claim: The words 'anything done or ordered to be done under this Act' do not mean any act in violation of the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Second, the words anything done or ordered to be done under this Act in the section do not mean any act in violation of the provisions of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Violations and omissions are 'anything done' per General Clauses Act definition; includes non-compliance with rules; supported by precedents like Pritam Singh, Maulud Ahmad, Sitaram

arguments.claim: The protection given under the section is only for actions done inadvertently or mistakenly but not for acts done deliberately and maliciously

anchor.surface_text: Third, the protection given to Government servants under the section is for actions done inadvertently or mistakenly but not for acts done deliberately and maliciously.

arguments.court_reasoning: No good faith requirement in sub-section (2), unlike sub-section (1); applies regardless of intent

arguments.claim: The section applies to prosecution of the respondents for violation of the provisions of the Rules and the Act

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contention on the other hand is that the section applies to prosecution of the respondents for violation of the provisions of the Rules and the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 40(2) bars prosecutions after 6 months for anything done under the Act, including rule violations by any person

arguments.claim: Prosecutions were instituted after expiry of six months from the date of the alleged offences

anchor.surface_text: It is further said on behalf of the respondents that they were rightly acquitted by the High Court because the prosecution were instituted subsequent to the expiry of six months

court_response_anchor.surface_text: July, 1964 and the companyplaint was filed on 18 May, 1965. In Criminal Appeal No. 195 of 1969 the acts companyplained of occurred on 20 June, 1964 a

arguments.claim: Provisions of section 40(2) do not apply to prosecution for offences committed by individuals in contravention of the Act and Rules

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the appellant contended that the provisions of the section did not apply to prosecution for offences committed by individuals in contravention of the Act and the Rules

court_response_anchor.surface_text: een instituted within four months from the date of the act companyplained of. The Bombay statute typifies in section 24 2  limitation of suit and pros

arguments.court_reasoning: Sub(2) applies to any person; no restriction to govt servants

arguments.claim: Section 40(1) and 40(2) operate in different fields; sub(2) has no restriction to govt servants

anchor.surface_text: The first sub-section speaks of bar of suits against the Central Government or against any officer of the Government... The two subsections operate in different fields.

arguments.claim: Sub-section 40(2) applies to any individual or person without words of qualification

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 does not have any words of qualification as to persons. Therefore, subsection 2 is applicable to any individual or person.

arguments.claim: Other statutes explicitly limit limitation to govt/officers when intended (e.g., Medicinal Excise s20, Madras GST s50, etc.)
'Anything done or ordered to be done under the Act' includes violations and illegal omissions per General Clauses Act
Precedents confirm limitation applies to non-compliance/violations by any person (Pritam Singh, Maulud Ahmad, Sitaram)
Rule violations (e.g., improper banderols, accounts) are infractions under the Act
Prosecution barred by limitation as complaints filed after 6 months

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 194... the Sub-Divisional Magistrate... held that the bar of limitation under the section applied... computing the period of six months... 25 January, 1965.

arguments.claim: Bar of limitation under section 40(2) operated against the State

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge... held that the bar of limitation under the section operated against the State because the prosecution was commenced after the expiry...

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of section 40 does not have any words of qualification as to persons and is applicable to any individual or person

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 does not have any words of qualification as to persons. Therefore, subsection 2 is applicable to any individual or person. Referance may be made to some statutes to indicate as to how the Legislature places bar against any class of person in respect of suits,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike sub-section (1) which explicitly protects Central Government and officers acting in good faith, sub-section (2) lacks any restricting words and has wide amplitude; legislature uses explicit limits in other statutes when intended

holdings.text: Section 40(2) cannot be said to be confined in its operation only to Government servants; applicable to any person against whom prosecution lies for anything done under the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of wide amplitude apply to prosecutions against respondents; rejected appellant's contention based on statutory text and comparison with other acts

holdings.text: The words 'anything done or ordered to be done under the Act' extend to illegal omissions and infractions including violations of Rules like improper affixing of banderols and maintenance of accounts

anchor.surface_text: The word act is defined in the General Clauses Act,1897. The definition is as follows act used with reference to an offence or a civil wrong, shall include a series of acts and words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal ommissions. The words anything done or ordered to be done under the Act in section 40 2

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of 'act' in General Clauses Act includes series of acts and illegal omissions; applied to non-compliance with statutory requirements for banderols, stock accounts, and duty payment

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of section 40 does not introduce the test of good faith; protection applies regardless of intent, unlike sub-section (1)
holdings.reasoning_summary: No mention of good faith or inadvertence in sub(2); deliberate evasion via cut banderols still covered as violation under the Act

holdings.text: Non-compliance with provisions of the statute by omitting to do what the Act enjoins constitutes 'anything done or ordered to be done under the Act'
holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by precedents (Pritam Singh, Maulud Ahmad, Sitaram) where limitation barred prosecutions for neglect of duty, false entries, false returns as acts/omissions under respective Acts

holdings.text: The prosecutions against respondents for violations of Central Excise Rules and sections 9(b),(d) are barred by limitation under section 40(2) as instituted after six months

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls for consideration in these appeals is the interpretation of section 40 2 of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 hereinafter referred to for brevity as the Section and the Act. The section is as follows No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall be instituted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied interpretation of s40(2) to facts: complaints filed after 6 months from acts (25 Jul 1964 & 20 Jun 1964); upheld lower courts' acquittals on limitation

precedents.citation: Pritam Singh v. State of Haryana 1 1971 1 S.C.C. 653

anchor.surface_text: In Pritam Singh v. State of Haryana 1  a Police Officer was Prosecuted for offences under section 29 of the Police Act. Section 42 of the Police, Act enacted that prosecution against any person which may be lawfully brought for anything done or intended to be done under the provisions of the Act shall be companymenced within three months after the act companyplained  1  1971 1 S.C.C. 653.

precedents.case_name: Pritam Singh v. State of Haryana
precedents.cited_proposition: Prosecution for non-compliance with duty requirements under the Police Act is covered by the limitation provision for 'anything done or intended to be done under the provisions of the Act'
precedents.cited_holding: Prosecution initiated for non-compliance with duty as required under the Police Act was held to be for something done under the provisions of the Act

precedents.citation: Maulud Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 38

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Maulud Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1  companysidered the case of prosecution of a head Constable. Section 42 of the Police Act was invoked as a bar to the prosecution in Maulud Ahmads 1  case  supra  the question was whether Chauhan abetted Maulud Ahmad in making false entries in the General Diary of Police Station Mailani and whether Maulud Ahmad made false entries in the General Diary of Police Station Mailani with the intention to save or knowing it likely that he would thereby save the offenders from legal punishment.

precedents.case_name: Maulud Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Failure to discharge duty in keeping records under the Police Act constitutes an offence under the Act, covered by limitation for acts done under the Act
precedents.cited_holding: If the appellant did number discharge his duty in keeping a regular diary he has companymitted an offence under section 29 of the Act

precedents.citation: Sitaram v. State of Madhya Pradesh 2 1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 21

anchor.surface_text: Sitaram v. State of Madhya Pradesh  2   this Court examined a criminal trial in respect of the offence of filing false returns of sales tax. Section 26 of the C.P. and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 provided inter alia, that numberprosecution shall be instituted against any person in respect of anything done or intended to be done under the Act unless the prosecution has been instituted within three months of the date of the act companyplained of.

precedents.case_name: Sitaram v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Limitation provision using 'any person' applies to prosecutions for violations like filing false returns under the Act, not restricted to government servants; acts done under the Act include submitting returns and accounts
precedents.cited_holding: The words 'any person' not restricted to government servants; filing returns and producing accounts under the Act are covered by the limitation

precedents.citation: Amalgameted Electricity Co. v. Municipal Committee, Ajmer 1

anchor.surface_text: In Amalgameted Electricity Co. v. Municipal Committee, Ajmer 1  the meaning of omission of a statutory duty was explained by this Court. Hegde, J. speaking for the Court said The omission in question must have a positive companytent in it. In other words, the number-discharge of that duty must amount to an illegality.

precedents.case_name: Amalgamated Electricity Co. v. Municipal Committee, Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: Omission of a statutory duty has positive content if non-discharge amounts to illegality
precedents.cited_holding: The omission in question must have a positive companytent in it. In other words, the number-discharge of that duty must amount to an illegality

anchor.surface_text: The words in section 40 2  of the Act in the present case are of wide amplitude to apply to ,the prosecution which was companymenced against the respondents in the present appeals. Section 40 2  of the Act cannot be said to be companyfied in its operation only to Government servants. The sub-section is applicable to any person against whom suits or proceedings or prosecution shall lie for anything, done or ordered to be done under the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Prosecution of respondents held barred by limitation under Section 40(2) of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls for consideration in these appeals is the interpretation of section 40 2 of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 hereinafter referred to for brevity as the Section and the Act. The section is as follows No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall be instituted

The words in section 40 2  of the Act in the present case are of wide amplitude to apply to ,the prosecution which was companymenced against the respondents in the present appeals. Section 40 2  of the Act cannot be said to be companyfied in its operation only to Government servants. The sub-section is applicable to any person against whom suits or proceedings or prosecution shall lie for anything, done or ordered to be done under the Act.
